title: Ground Truth
description: VAST Challenge 2013 information about the data and scenario

annotations.eventDetail: Videoconference between Big Marketing and Total Crop Protection Services
Letter sent to Big Marketing from Butterfly Warriors

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: Attacker shows up as source IP against 172.30.0.x machines [Note: Qualifies as subtle because firewall allows mainly ports 25 and 80]
BB: Server machines should continue to report regularly
annotations.eventDetail: Port scans against Site 3 from one attacker (10.6.6.6)

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Netflow : Regular to high volume web browsing traffic to the server(s) followed by portscans. Attacker shows as source IP against 172.30.0.x
annotations.eventDetail: Attacker 10.7.7.10  recons the www.bigmkt3.com server(s) followed by portscanning

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Netflow: Many connections with short duration, small payloads
annotations.eventDetail: Part 1: DOS attempt: www.bigmkt3.com is attacked by 10 attackers

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: No records with server as source from 7:02-7:16
BB: No records for server from 6:54-7:45
annotations.eventDetail: Part 2: Server crash: www.bigmkt3.com becomes unresponsive temporarily due to DOS #1

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Netflow: www.bigmkt3.com now shows as responding to  traffic
annotations.eventDetail: Part 3: Server return: www.bigmkt3.com returns to the network.

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: Attackers show up as source IP against 172.30.0.x machines [Note: Qualifies as subtle because firewall allows mainly ports 25 and 80]
BB: Server machines should continue to report regularly (except wwwbigmkt3.com - which has crashed)
annotations.eventDetail:
Port scans against Site 3 from one attacker (10.6.6.6)
Also, attacker 10.7.7.10 recons www.bigmkt3.com

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: Many connections with short duration, small payloads
BB: Servers continue to report. Minimal trending toward resource use (memory/cpu)
annotations.eventDetail:
Part 1: DOS attempt: 10 attackers DOS www.bigmkt3.com;
5 attackers DOS www.bigmkt2.com

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: <same>
annotations.eventDetail: One additional attacker (10.15.7.85) goes after a different bgmkt2 web server (web02l.bigmkt.com)

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Cannot see in the data
annotations.eventDetail: Part 1: Origin of infection: www.bigmkt2.com is compromised and a malicious redirect is added to a web page

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: Most netflow shows durationSeconds=0. Hard to say it fully crashed, since there is still data as both Src/Dest
BB: No records for server 11:26-11:51
annotations.eventDetail: Part 2: Server crash: www.bigmkt3.com crashes due to DOS #2

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Netflow: Sessions connecting to www.bigmkt2.com exhibit shorter session durations and smaller payloads
annotations.eventDetail: Part 2: Redirects: All visitors to www.bigmkt2.com are redirected to a malicious web site, where the visiting computers can also become infected with malware
Part 3: Server return: www.bigmkt3.com returns to the network.

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Cannot see in the data
annotations.eventDetail: An administrator machine visits www.bigmkt2.com and is infected

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Cannot see in the data
annotations.eventDetail: Admin infection enables attackers to change firewall settings, opening all ports

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Netflow: Two ftp records (ports 20/21) between 10.7.5.5 and 172.10.0.40 with large payload
annotations.eventDetail: Admin infection enables FTP exfiltration of a large file (~110 MB) to 10.7.5.5.

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Netflow: Ports other than 25/80 show up with short duration, small payloads
annotations.eventDetail: Port scans against all Site 3 servers from attacker 10.9.81.5. These port scans show significantly more open firewall ports than previous port scans.

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Netflow: Ports other than 25/80 show up with short duration, small payloads
annotations.eventDetail: Port scans against all Site 2 servers from attacker 10.10.11.15

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Netflow: Two ftp records (ports 20/21) between 10.7.5.5 and 172.10.0.40 with large payload
annotations.eventDetail: FTP exfiltration of ~650MB file to 10.7.5.5
Big Marketing received follow up threat from Butterfly Warriors

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Complete gap in all data
annotations.eventDetail: Big Marketing takes network down to investigate security concerns and to install an IPS

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: Connections with short duration, small payloads
IPS: Deny messages for the source ip (code 106023)
annotations.eventDetail:
Multiple port scans against all Big Marketing sites (Sites 1, 2 and 3)
One attacker per site (1 = 10.13.77.29, 2 = 10.138.235.111, 3 = 10.6.6.7)

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: Connections with short duration, small payloads
IPS: Deny messages for the source ip (code 106023)
annotations.eventDetail: Port scans against Sites 1, 2, and 3 from attacker 10.12.15.152

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: high volume connections from attackers with a mix of duration and payload sizes
IPS: As the attack ramps up, some Deny messages (code 106023) for attacker IPs; the deny records appear with attacker in [source ip] and the NAT address of servers in [destintion ip]
annotations.eventDetail:
Failed DOS attack against Sites 1, 2 and 3 (5, 7 and 8 attackers, respectively).  The DOS incoming traffic is a blocked by the IPS to a degree that the servers continue to function
Site 1 goes to 12:39, Site 2 to 12:51, Site 3 to 12:57

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: IPS: Two blocked records (code 106023)
annotations.eventDetail: Attempted FTP session blocked by IPS

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: Connections with short duration, small payloads
IPS: Deny messages for the source ip (code 106023)
annotations.eventDetail:
Port scans against Sites 1, 2, and 3 from attacker 10.6.6.7
Port scans against site 2 continue into 4/12

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Netflow: Outbound connections to 10.4.20.8
annotations.eventDetail: Part 1: Origin of infection: Account managers navigate to external site hosting leaked customer data, become infected with botnet malware

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator: Netflow: SSH records with C2 server as destination
annotations.eventDetail: Part 2: Ongoing infection: Big Marketing machines infected by botnet communicate every 10 minutes via SSH to command and control server (10.0.3.77).

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: Connections with short duration, small payloads
IPS: Deny messages for the source ip (code 106023)
annotations.eventDetail: Port scans against Site 1 (attacker 10.12.15.152),  Site 2 (attacker 10.12.14.15) and Site 3 (attacker 10.250.178.101)

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: Connections with short duration, small payloads
IPS: Deny messages for the source ip (code 106023)
annotations.eventDetail: Port scans against Site 1 (attacker 10.17.15.10) and Site 3 (attacker 10.12.15.152)

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: small payload connection from internal machines to external
IPS:  regular built/teardown - no warn or errors
annotations.eventDetail: 8 Big Marketing machines start a DOS against an external machine (10.0.0.8)

annotations.dataSourceAndIndicator:
Netflow: small payload connection from internal machines to external
IPS:  regular built/teardown - no warn or errors
annotations.eventDetail: 8 Big Marketing machines start a DOS against an external machine (10.1.0.100)

IPS: Deny messages for the source ip (code 106023)
annotations.eventDetail:
Port scans against Sites 1, 2, and 3
One attacker per site (1 = 10.13.77.29, 2 = 10.138.235.111, 3 = 10.6.6.7)

annotations.eventDetail:
